name: Chocolate Idiot Cake
description:
Adapted from Ready for Dessert (Ten Speed Press)

This cake is extremely rich, and tastes like the most delicious, silkiest, most supremely-chocolate ganache you’ve ever had. As mentioned, it’s equally good a few days later, and only an idiot could possibly mess it up. Use a good chocolate — you’ll appreciate it when you taste your first melt-in-your-mouth bite.

Make sure to wrap the springform pan very well in foil, perhaps in several layers, to prevent any water seeping in during baking.
recipeIngredient: 10 ounces (290gr) bittersweet or semisweet chocolate (coarsely chopped)
7 ounces (200gr) butter (salted or unsalted, cut into pieces)
unsweetened cocoa powder (for preparing the cake pan)

recipeInstructions.text: Butter a 9-inch (23cm) springform pan and dust it with cocoa powder, tapping out any excess. Wrap the outside with aluminum foil, in several layers if necessary (see headnote), making sure it goes all the way up to the outer rim.
recipeInstructions.name: Butter a 9-inch (23cm) springform pan and dust it with cocoa powder, tapping out any excess. Wrap the outside with aluminum foil, in several layers if necessary (see headnote), making sure it goes all the way up to the outer rim.

recipeInstructions.text: Melt the chocolate and butter in a double boiler (or microwave), stirring occasionally, until smooth. Remove from heat.
recipeInstructions.name: Melt the chocolate and butter in a double boiler (or microwave), stirring occasionally, until smooth. Remove from heat.

recipeInstructions.text: In a large bowl, whisk together the eggs and sugar, then whisk in the melted chocolate mixture until smooth.
recipeInstructions.name: In a large bowl, whisk together the eggs and sugar, then whisk in the melted chocolate mixture until smooth.

recipeInstructions.text: Pour the batter into the prepared springform pan and cover the top of the cake pan snugly with a sheet of foil. Put the springform pan into a larger baking pan, such as a roasting pan, and add enough hot water to the baking pan to reach halfway up to the outside of the cake pan.
recipeInstructions.name: Pour the batter into the prepared springform pan and cover the top of the cake pan snugly with a sheet of foil. Put the springform pan into a larger baking pan, such as a roasting pan, and add enough hot water to the baking pan to reach halfway up to the outside of the cake pan.

recipeInstructions.text: Bake the cake for about 1 hour and 15 minutes. It should feels just set in the center, like quivering chocolate pudding. If you gently touch the center, your finger should come away almost clean.
recipeInstructions.name: Bake the cake for about 1 hour and 15 minutes. It should feels just set in the center, like quivering chocolate pudding. If you gently touch the center, your finger should come away almost clean.

recipeInstructions.text: Lift the cake pan from the water bath and remove the foil. Let cake cool completely on a cooling rack.
recipeInstructions.name: Lift the cake pan from the water bath and remove the foil. Let cake cool completely on a cooling rack.

recipeInstructions.text: When cool, serve thin wedges of this very rich cake at room temperature, with crème anglaise, ice cream, or whipped cream. It could also be served with a drizzle of chocolate sauce.
